SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire too.

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

[Stamp: Received APR 15 1965]
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name (Mrs.) Lily Gay.

2. Your address Kimistino, Saskatchewan.

3. Date March 16, 1952.

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Liverpool, England.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Job Grundy, Traffic Manager, Mersey Docks & Harbour Board.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Arrived in Montreal, May 20th, 1900.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
   Twenty-six years.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   On the death of my father 1898, and on the invitation of my sister, Mother, myself and a brother came out.

   Mrs. Florence Roseoe.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    My brother-in-law James William Roseoe came out in 1881 as far as Winnipeg, worked around there for a little, then got taken on as carpenter on the Hudson Bay steamer The Lily which landed him in Prince Albert. He must have taken up a homestead here, about a mile or so north of the present town (which became just a few weeks ago) Kimistino. In 1886 he came back to England and from there I can remember he was trying to interest people in homesteading. Whilst there he married my sister, Florence, and in March 1887 they came out, stayed a few months in Prince Albert, then decided to live on their homestead, where their family was born and raised. The oldest boy, Carey, was born in November, 1887.
SASKATCHEWAN PIONEERS' GENEALOGY

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Cay Lily
2. Your address: Kimstimino, Saskatchewan
3. Date: March 16, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Liverpool, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Mr. Grundy, Harbour Board Manager, Mewey
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Arrived in Montreal, May 20, 1900
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to err.)
   I'm not sure, but I think I was about 18 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   On the death of my father 1898 and on the invitation of my aunt, mother myself and a brother came out.

Mrs. Florence Poole

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or Government information?)

My mother-in-law James William Poole came out in 1881 as far as Winnipeg, worked around there for a little while, then got taken on an engagement on the Hudson Bay Company. She met her husband, which landed him in Prince Albert. He must have taken up a homestead here about a mile or so north of the present town, which became just a few miles south of Prince Albert. In 1886 he came back to England and purchased land in Ontario. There he married my uncle, Florence and in March 1887 they came back to Prince Albert. They homesteaded in Prince Albert and stayed there until 1887.

The story of Cay Lily was born in November, 1887.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Just the three of us.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Steamer, Canadian to Montreal then by train to Regina. Stayed there for a couple of hours from 6-8 a.m., or so, branching up to Prince Albert, arriving there about 10 p.m. Spent the night there. Mr. Robert meetings us started out next day by demerat, arriving at his home sometime in the evening 50 miles from Prince Albert.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Winistino, M. Ross's homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Winistino, N.W quarter Sec:2, Range:45, Township:21, W.F:25

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Christopher Theodore Lay, April 24, 1901, Mr. Roscoe's home.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My youngest brother, Robert Cromiston Grundy, in March 1888. 1896, 1899, 1900 was in the Yukon Gold Rush. Homesteaded the next quarter to Mr. W. Roscoe.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

In the winter of 1901, on one night when it seemed desperately cold—we did have a thermometer and it was registering 50° below—about noon I went outside to see the moon glistening on the snow looking like so many diamonds, I thought I heard a voice. Naturally, I was shocked still for a moment, wondering whatever sound like that could be coming from the lake. On investigation my husband and I discovered a man with a team completely played out. He was a settler from Star City, about 8 miles east of us, had been to Prince Albert for supplies—8 miles from our place—he had got off the trail; his poor horses were halfway up the river in snow. We got them into the stable and went to bed. Next morning we discovered that a roll bag of flour & big bag of oatmeal & several other eatables were soaked in Coal Oil, the can having sprung a leak. Now he managed with the cats after that, we never heard.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

There was far too much to do to ever think of travelling further than a neighbour, who were as scarce as hen's teeth.

By team, usually.

At the time when Almighty Vace shot Constable Colebrook, his guide came to G.J. Lay's shack to tell him what had happened. (About three miles west of what is now Beatty, on the road to what is now Melfort.) He hitched onto his stoneboat a bottle of milk (hot) some whisky, blankets, had been shot into the heart, G.J. Lay with a neighbour Mr. Philip Burnie took the body to Adams Crossing, now Denton, north Saskatchewan River.
17. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Christopher Sherrill Gray April 24, 1941. Mr. Reeves' home.

21. Did anyone else come to Castle Rock? Because of your recommendation, it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My youngest brother, Robert Cromwell Gray, in March 1858.

1843/1849 I was on the Yellow Gold Rush.

Commenced the west quarter of 9 in 1862.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

In the autumn of 1901 we were obliged to remain at home during the cold weather due to a severe snowstorm and remained there for five weeks. We had about 10 inches of snow outside. To see the snow, I thought it looked like a scene out of a fairy tale. Everything was covered in snow, including my surroundings. It was beautiful and I thought it was a wonderland. I thought it was a dream come true.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? How often?

25. Have you ever been away from home for more than two weeks?

By team, usually.

At the time when Almighty Voice sent Constable Coleborne, his guide came to G. J. Gray's shack to tell him what had happened. He said that Mr. Gray of what is now Beatty, on the road to us, was so near death that he wished only his children back to town. I went to see him and he told me that he had been sick for many months and that he was very weak.

Mr. Philip Brame, forty-three, to Adams County, New Mexico.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Mr. J.W. Roseoe was elected town councilman in 1900. He was a member of the Kinistino Agricultural Society, followed by R.C. Grundy. Later someone else took over.

It has now been dead for some years.

In connection with it, a lending library was started.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

When Mr. Roseoe left the farm he started a furniture store in the new Village of Kinistino where he was very busy getting a real school built.

When the railway came through 1904-1905, many more new settlers came in. There was a rail station.

1905 a hotel was built. 1905 date that Kinistino was formed.
